channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: Super Bowl is our ‘Word of the Week’ courtesy of Bad Bunny
This Week in Explainers: Can Bangladesh’s Tarique Rahman mend ties with India?
How Pentagon used Anthropic’s Claude AI to capture Nicolas Maduro
India turns highway into runway for emergency landing near China border. Why this matters
Spicing it up: What are vinegar Valentine cards?
Who is Nikhil Gupta, who has pleaded guilty in the Pannun assassination plot?
Bangladesh polls: Tarique Rahman’s resounding victory comes with a crown of thorns
item.description: With a two-thirds majority, BNP leader Tarique Rahman must now act decisively to meet the formidable challenges and honour his lofty promises. He would do well to remember that public memory is short, Bangladesh’s youth are restless, and its generals have historically not remained indifferent observers

item.title: How Bangladesh polls prick the ‘Gen Z revolution’ bubble and leave students in the lurch
item.description: Protesting students gathered on the streets in pursuit of true democracy but ended up as puppets for the designs of the deep state

item.title: Why Trump is rebuffing Netanyahu’s push for a tougher stance on Iran
item.description: The US president has stated that reaching a diplomatic deal with Iran is his ‘preference’

item.title: Exploring Bareilly: From Mahabharata legends to Ahichchhatra ruins
item.description: Bareilly was once the focal point of the kingdom of Uttara Panchala, one of the most significant places in the Mahabharat story. It was said to be ruled by Draupad, father of Draupadi, who was also called Panchali

item.title: When graffiti becomes history: Indian imprints in the land of Pharaohs and beyond
item.description: While ancient Indian graffiti in Egypt may be in the news right now, historical graffiti are not rare either in India or elsewhere in the world

item.title: How Saudi Arabia’s embrace of ‘Axis of Ikhwan’ shatters the IMEC dream
item.description: Mohammed Bin Salman might keep the illusion of participation open—all the better to play into the wishful thinking of the West that does not want to acknowledge the loss of Saudi Arabia—but India should be under no illusion
